chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of roundworm
chapter.summary: Covers the management of a person with confirmed roundworm infestation in primary care.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a roundworm infestation?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange urgent admission for anyone presenting with possible complications of roundworm infection such as intestinal or biliary obstruction.
    • Seek advice from a specialist in infectious diseases if systemic features of roundworm (such as cough and pneumonitis) are suspected, or unsure of the diagnosis or management.
  • For people with confirmed (stool positive) uncomplicated Ascaris infection:
    • Provide oral and written information on the diagnosis:
      • Sources of advice for healthcare professionals include the Hospital for Tropical Diseases, the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine and the National Travel Health Network and Centre (NaTHNaC).
      • Patient information on roundworm can be found on the NHS website.
    • Treat with an antihelminth medication such as mebendazole (unless contraindicated) — treatment is usually given as a single dose (unlicensed) or in divided doses over 3 days.
      • Mebendazole is unlicensed for use in pregnant or breastfeeding women and children under the age of 2 years. For treatment of roundworm in children under the age of 2 years and pregnant or breastfeeding women, seek advice from an infectious disease specialist.
      • Advise the person that transient abdominal pain, nausea or diarrhoea may occur with treatment especially in heavy infestations.
    • Give advice on hygiene measures to prevent reinfection or transmission to others:
      • Wash hands with soap and warm water before handling food or eating and after using the toilet, changing nappies or contact with animals or manure.
      • Wash, peel, or cook all raw vegetables and fruits before eating especially if grown in soil that has been fertilized with manure or wastewater.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of Ascaris infection are based on the clinical guidelines Guidance. Helminth infections: migrant health guide [PHE, 2014], Parasites – ascariasis [CDC, 2018a] and the Yellow Book. Chapter 3. Infectious diseases related to travel. Helminths, soil transmitted [CDC, 2018b], expert opinion in review articles [Imhoff-Kunsch, 2012] [Lamberton, 2015] [Weatherhead, 2015] [BMJ Best Practice, 2017; Jourdan, 2017] and the manufacturer Summary of product characteristics [ABPI, 2016].

Arrange admission for people with suspected complications of roundworm infection
  • This is a pragmatic recommendation based on the fact that some complications of roundworm infestations (for example intestinal and biliary tract obstruction) can be life-threatening.
Treatment of uncomplicated confirmed Ascaris infection
  • Public Health England [PHE, 2014], the World Health Organization [WHO, 2017]  and Centres for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC, 2018b] recommend treatment of Ascaris infection with antihelminthic drugs such as albendazole or mebendazole as these drugs are generally effective and appear to have few side-effects.
  • The British National Formulary (BNF) states that mebendazole is effective against Ascaris lumbricoides and is generally considered to be the drug of choice.
    • Mebendazole is not licensed for use as a single dose of 500mg in roundworm infections or for treatment of children under the age of 2 years [BNF 74, 2017].
    • Albendazole is an unlicensed drug [BNF 74, 2017].
  • A systematic review and meta-analysis (44 studies, n=7273) looking at A. lumbricoides cure rates and egg reduction rates (n = 33 studies) found that single-dose regimens of albendazole, mebendazole, levamisole, and pyrantel pamoate were were highly efficacious [Moser, 2017] .
    • Estimated average cure rates were 96.2% (92.3–98.1%) for mebendazole.
    • The estimated egg reduction rate for mebendazole was 98.0% (94–100%).
  • A review summarizing efficacy data from 29 studies looking at single dose 500mg mebendazole found a cure rate of 92.6% (range 72.5-100%) for A. lumbricoides. The egg reduction rate for A. lumbricoides was 97.9% (range 89.8-100%) [Mrus, 2017].
Treatment of young children
  • The Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) state that the safety of mebendazole in children has not been established and there is limited data on use of mebendazole in children aged 2 years or younger [CDC, 2018b]  — seek advice before prescribing.
Treatment of breastfeeding or pregnant women
  • No antihelminth drugs are licenced in pregnancy — the manufacturer recommends avoidance in breastfeeding and pregnancy as toxicity has been demonstrated in animal studies [ABPI, 2016; BNF 74, 2017].
  • CDC note that the World Health Organization allows use of mebendazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of pregnancy — risk of treatment in pregnant women with confirmed infection needs to be balanced with risk of disease progression without treatment [CDC, 2018b].
  • Limited data indicate that mebendazole is poorly excreted into breastmilk and poorly absorbed orally. Reports on the use of mebendazole during breastfeeding have found no adverse reactions in breastfed infants. There are rare case reports of a decrease in milk supply following use of mebendazole, but no convincing evidence that these were caused by the drug [Lactmed, 2017].
